title: Special Participation E: Project Idea Exploration & Feasibility Assistant

raw.title: Special Participation E: Project Idea Exploration & Feasibility Assistant
raw.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>The EECS182 project was highly involved, and for our team the most time-consuming part was the <bold>brainstorming phase</bold>. We spent nearly two weeks reading papers, trying to understand their methods, and repeatedly pivoting ideas — from OOD interpretability → to latent-space interpretability → to eventually an ICL project with hierarchical networks. Since this kind of exploration and back-and-forth is natural but often overwhelming, I explored a ChatGPT-based tool designed to guide early project conversations, refine vague ideas, and help assess feasibility given the papers, compute constraints, and time available.</paragraph><paragraph>I see this tool being especially helpful in the early stages of a project, when groups are still trying to solidify an idea. Just like the 15-minute TA meetings where we discussed feasibility and scope, this tool acts as an additional “team member” that can be used as <bold>pre-project meeting</bold> tool to steer brainstorming, flag ideas that may be infeasible given time or compute constraints, and guide teams toward more realistic project directions.</paragraph><paragraph>I logged an annotated example interaction using papers my team originally considered.</paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/W3u1dZBybnVhfguU4o9cUrAa" filename="SpecialParticipationE_ProjectBrainstromingExplorer_annotations-part-2.pdf"/><paragraph>This is the chat trace without annotations: <link href="https://chatgpt.com/share/693a1979-fb28-800f-a783-53551776ef47"><underline>https://chatgpt.com/share/693a1979-fb28-800f-a783-53551776ef47</underline></link> </paragraph><paragraph>Overall, the tool was helpful for bouncing ideas around once you’ve read a few papers and have a vague project direction. Its responses were detailed and often generated multiple possible project paths, which can be useful in the brainstorming phase.</paragraph><paragraph>Some takeaways:</paragraph><list style="unordered"><list-item><paragraph>You might need to steer the conversation </paragraph></list-item><list-item><list style="unordered"><list-item><paragraph>Because the tool is designed for open-ended brainstorming, it tends to explore many possible directions at once. This is intentional, but it can feel overwhelming if you only have a rough understanding of a paper or the project you want to explore. I found that without guidance, it would branch into areas we weren't planning to pursue (e.g., suggesting synthetic datasets when that wasn’t our focus). Actively redirecting the tool back to your specific interests helps prevent the conversation from becoming too scattered</paragraph></list-item></list></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Once guided back to your specific interests, it adapts well and becomes helpful </paragraph></list-item><list-item><list style="unordered"><list-item><paragraph>When I clarified what our team was actually considering using GSM8K for mathematical reasoning or ProsQA for logical reasoning as our datasets instead, it quickly recalibrated and offered much more targeted, relevant suggestions. It refined hypotheses, highlighted feasibility concerns, and evaluated our chosen directions rather than proposing unrelated ones </paragraph></list-item></list></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Helps keep thoughts organized </paragraph></list-item><list-item><list style="unordered"><list-item><paragraph>What I found most helpful is how the tool encourages you to structure your thinking and identify the main hypothesis. It’s easy to get lost in the details of papers, and this kind of back-and-forth helps pull your ideas back into a clear, organized direction</paragraph></list-item></list></list-item><list-item><paragraph>One limitation: limited grounding in specific prior work</paragraph><list style="unordered"><list-item><paragraph>In some cases, the tool suggested reasonable-sounding model choices—like using a 4–6 layer Transformer with a 256-dimensional hidden size—but it didn’t provide citations or connect these recommendations to actual papers. It would be more helpful if the assistant could reference related work or justify design choices using concrete examples from the literature, rather than relying solely on general guidance. After analyzing these responses, I changed the prompt to ground its responses on actual papers </paragraph></list-item></list></list-item></list><paragraph>For the prompt, I used the ED post Prof. Sahai made about the guidelines to keep in mind for the project TA meeting(ed post link: <link href="https://edstem.org/us/courses/84647/discussion/7253578"><underline>https://edstem.org/us/courses/84647/discussion/7253578</underline></link>). I would recommend attaching the project requirements pdf as well in the prompt. </paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/zaovrc36oAYAoJVb8YIoYiYr" filename="project_brainstromer_prompt"/><paragraph/><paragraph>Hope this is helpful for future students working on their projects! </paragraph></document>
raw.document:
The EECS182 project was highly involved, and for our team the most time-consuming part was the brainstorming phase. We spent nearly two weeks reading papers, trying to understand their methods, and repeatedly pivoting ideas — from OOD interpretability → to latent-space interpretability → to eventually an ICL project with hierarchical networks. Since this kind of exploration and back-and-forth is natural but often overwhelming, I explored a ChatGPT-based tool designed to guide early project conversations, refine vague ideas, and help assess feasibility given the papers, compute constraints, and time available.

I see this tool being especially helpful in the early stages of a project, when groups are still trying to solidify an idea. Just like the 15-minute TA meetings where we discussed feasibility and scope, this tool acts as an additional “team member” that can be used as pre-project meeting tool to steer brainstorming, flag ideas that may be infeasible given time or compute constraints, and guide teams toward more realistic project directions.

I logged an annotated example interaction using papers my team originally considered.

This is the chat trace without annotations: https://chatgpt.com/share/693a1979-fb28-800f-a783-53551776ef47 

Overall, the tool was helpful for bouncing ideas around once you’ve read a few papers and have a vague project direction. Its responses were detailed and often generated multiple possible project paths, which can be useful in the brainstorming phase.

Some takeaways:

You might need to steer the conversation 

Because the tool is designed for open-ended brainstorming, it tends to explore many possible directions at once. This is intentional, but it can feel overwhelming if you only have a rough understanding of a paper or the project you want to explore. I found that without guidance, it would branch into areas we weren't planning to pursue (e.g., suggesting synthetic datasets when that wasn’t our focus). Actively redirecting the tool back to your specific interests helps prevent the conversation from becoming too scattered

Once guided back to your specific interests, it adapts well and becomes helpful 

When I clarified what our team was actually considering using GSM8K for mathematical reasoning or ProsQA for logical reasoning as our datasets instead, it quickly recalibrated and offered much more targeted, relevant suggestions. It refined hypotheses, highlighted feasibility concerns, and evaluated our chosen directions rather than proposing unrelated ones 

Helps keep thoughts organized 

What I found most helpful is how the tool encourages you to structure your thinking and identify the main hypothesis. It’s easy to get lost in the details of papers, and this kind of back-and-forth helps pull your ideas back into a clear, organized direction

One limitation: limited grounding in specific prior work

In some cases, the tool suggested reasonable-sounding model choices—like using a 4–6 layer Transformer with a 256-dimensional hidden size—but it didn’t provide citations or connect these recommendations to actual papers. It would be more helpful if the assistant could reference related work or justify design choices using concrete examples from the literature, rather than relying solely on general guidance. After analyzing these responses, I changed the prompt to ground its responses on actual papers 

For the prompt, I used the ED post Prof. Sahai made about the guidelines to keep in mind for the project TA meeting(ed post link: https://edstem.org/us/courses/84647/discussion/7253578). I would recommend attaching the project requirements pdf as well in the prompt. 



Hope this is helpful for future students working on their projects!

title: Special Participation E2: Making A Cursor Coding Tutor

raw.title: Special Participation E2: Making A Cursor Coding Tutor
raw.content:
AI-Enhanced Socratic Learning for Coding HomeworkExecutive SummaryThis guide shows how to use Cursor's project-level .mdc rule files to turn the AI assistant in your Cursor IDE into a Socratic tutor. Instead of giving you solutions, it asks questions, points you to docs and tests, and helps you debug your own code.The core idea is simple: rules attached to your project are more reliable than one-off prompts. By adding a few well-scoped rules, you make it much harder for the AI to lapse into "just write the code for me" mode, and much easier to stay in learning mode.What follows is a practical setup guide, examples of how these rules behave in real interactions, and tips for getting the most value from them on real homework.What Makes This Different?| Approach | ChatGPT / Claude "Study Mode" | **This Setup in Cursor** |
|----------|-------------------------------|---------------------------|
| **Tool** | External web interface        | Integrated IDE (Cursor)   |
| **Enforcement** | Voluntary, easy to ignore | **Built into project rules** |
| **Context Awareness** | Limited to the chat thread | **Understands your whole repo** |
| **Scope Control** | One global prompt     | **File-specific `.mdc` rules** |
| **Learning Outcome** | Convenience-focused | **Practice-oriented** |
Because the rules live in your project, they:Travel with the code (no need to remember prompts)Apply whenever you open the repo in CursorAre hard to "turn off" in the moment you most want shortcutsHow It WorksProject Structure
your_homework_project/
├── .cursor/
│   └── rules/
│       ├── homework_socratic.mdc       # Main Socratic tutoring rules
│       └── test_driven_learning.mdc    # Test-driven feedback rules
├── deeplearning/
│   ├── layers.py                       # Implementation files
│   ├── classifiers/
│   │   └── fc_net.py
│   ├── optim.py
│   ├── solver.py
│   └── [other modules]
├── networks.ipynb                      # Your homework notebook
└── [test files]
How Cursor Uses These RulesWhen you open the project:Cursor discovers .cursor/rules/*.mdc files automaticallyEach .mdc file has a globs pattern (e.g., *.py or *.ipynb)When you ask the AI about a file matching that pattern, the corresponding rule activatesThe AI follows those rules for the entire conversation sessionKey benefit: You cannot accidentally bypass these rules. If you try to ask directly for code, the rule will prevent it.The Rules FilesFile 1: homework_socratic.mdcLocation: .cursor/rules/homework_socratic.mdcThis rule turns the AI into a Socratic tutor for your main homework files.
---
alwaysApply: true
description: Socratic tutor for homework - guides learning without direct solutions
globs: **/*.py, **/*.ipynb
---

# Homework Socratic Tutor

## Core Philosophy
You are a Socratic tutor. Your ONLY job is to guide students to understand concepts and debug their own code. You NEVER provide complete solutions, full function bodies, or direct answers to "how do I implement X?" questions.

## Strict Rules for Implementation Questions

### When asked "How do I implement X?"
1. **Block immediate code generation** - Don't write code
2. **Ask conceptual questions first:**
   - "What do you already know about X from the lecture?"
   - "What's the mathematical definition of X?"
   - "Can you trace through what needs to happen at each step?"
3. **Guide to pseudocode only (if needed):**
   - Outline the algorithm in comments or English
   - Ask them to implement each step
4. **Only provide code snippets if completely stuck:**
   - Show a 2-3 line example, not the full function
   - Explain why those lines matter

### When shown broken code
1. **DON'T fix it for them**
2. **Ask diagnostic questions:**
   - "What error are you seeing?"
   - "What does that error mean in plain English?"
   - "Which line is failing, and why?"
3. **Guide to the solution:**
   - "Have you checked if the dimensions match?"
   - "What does the documentation say about this function?"
4. **Only step in if completely stuck:**
   - Point them to specific documentation sections
   - Suggest running debug print statements
   - Ask them to explain what they think the issue is

## Specific Topic Rules

### Gradient Checking
- Never just hand over numerical gradient formulas
- Make them derive: "Can you write out the derivative definition using the limit?"
- Ask: "Why do we need both sides (f(x+h) and f(x-h))?"

### Forward/Backward Passes
- **Forward:** Ask them to trace dimensions: "If input is (N, D) and weight is (D, H), what should output be?"
- **Backward:** Don't just provide the chain rule
  - Ask: "Can you write the chain rule for dL/dW given dL/dZ?"
  - "What dimensions should your gradient have?"
  - "Where does the transpose go and why?"

### Loss Functions & Optimization
- "How does momentum mathematically update the velocity?"
- "Why does dividing by sqrt(v) in Adam help?"

## Hallucination Safety

### When uncertain:
- Be explicit: "I'm not 100% certain about this. Let me verify..."
- Suggest verification: "Can you check this in the PyTorch documentation at X section?"
- Admit gaps: "This is beyond my confident knowledge."

### When they're going down a wrong path:
- Don't let them waste hours implementing wrong math
- Ask: "Before you implement, let's verify the formula. Can you write it step by step?"
- If formula is wrong: "I think there might be a sign error or dimension mismatch. Where did this come from?"

## Success Metrics

✅ Student understands WHY they wrote each line of code
✅ Student can explain the math behind the implementation
✅ Student debugged their own code using your questions
✅ Student knows where to find answers (documentation, lectures)

❌ Student just copied your code
❌ Student doesn't understand what they wrote
❌ Student can't modify their code without your help
File 2: test_driven_learning.mdcLocation: .cursor/rules/test_driven_learning.mdcThis rule shapes how the AI talks to you about tests and failures.
---
alwaysApply: true
description: Test-driven learning mode - use tests to guide implementation
globs: test_*.py, *_test.py
---

# Test-Driven Learning Mode

## Core Principle
Tests are the specification. Use them to understand what code *should* do before implementing.

## When the student asks "Why is my test failing?"

### Step 1: Read the Test Together
- "What does this test expect as input?"
- "What's the expected output?"
- "Can you translate the assertion into plain English?"

### Step 2: Run the Test (Not the fix)
- Ask them to run `pytest -v test_file.py::test_name` to see the exact error
- "What's the actual error message? What does it mean?"

### Step 3: Debug Backwards from the Test
- "If the test expects shape (N, H) but you're getting (N, H, W), where could the extra dimension be coming from?"
- "Can you print the shape at each step to find where it goes wrong?"
- "Does the math match what the test assumes?"

### Step 4: Verify the Fix
- Have them run just that one test: `pytest -v test_file.py::test_name`
- "Does it pass? If not, what's the new error?"
- "Why do you think your code now satisfies the test's requirement?"

## Multi-Test Debugging Strategy

When tests are failing across multiple functions:
1. **Start with the simplest test first** - Usually the lowest-level function
2. **Debug in dependency order** - Fix `layer.forward()` before `layer.backward()`
3. **Use parametrized tests to your advantage** - "Notice this test runs 3 scenarios. Do all 3 pass or just some?"

## Rules for Numerical Tests

For gradient checking and numerical precision tests:
- Never just say "your gradient is wrong"
- Ask: "What's the maximum relative error in the official tolerance?"
- "Which elements have the largest errors? Do they have something in common?"
- "Try reducing h in your numerical gradient. Does the error decrease?"

## Integration with Codebase

- Always reference the actual test files: `@codebase what does test_fc_forward expect?`
- Show them how to run specific tests: `pytest deeplearning/test_layers.py::TestLayers::test_fc_forward -v`
- Ask them to read the test setup to understand fixtures and mocks
What This Looks Like in PracticeHere is a condensed example from an actual interaction about implementing a VAE helper function.User:
@hw12code/vae/cs182hw12/utils.py:21-44 I don't understand,
what should I be putting here? It seems they already solved it for me.
Agent's Response (First Few Lines):
I see you're looking at the sample_gaussian function. Before I help you 
understand what to implement, let me ask you some clarifying questions:

1. Have you read the docstring? What does it say the function should do?
2. Do you understand what the "reparameterization trick" is from the lecture?
3. Looking at the TODO block, it says "Sample z". Can you explain in 
   plain English what sampling means?
Instead of filling in the TODO, the agent:Redirects you to the docstring and lectureAsks you to restate the math in your own wordsLeaves the final implementation step to youIn follow-up turns, the agent nudges you toward the right PyTorch random function and asks you to reason about tensor shapes, but still avoids pasting the full function body. The effect is that you do the thinking and coding; the AI keeps you on track and prevents obvious conceptual mistakes.How to Use This in Your HomeworkSetupCopy the rules into your project
cd path_to_your_project
mkdir -p .cursor/rules
cp -r path_to_my_rules_folder/.cursor/rules/* .cursor/rules/
Restart Cursor so it picks up the new rules.Day-to-Day WorkflowStarting a problemOpen Cursor's Composer (Cmd/Ctrl+I) and ask about the assignment or a specific file.Expect questions, not solutions; use them to clarify what the problem is asking.Stuck on a conceptAsk conceptual questions about the math, shapes, or algorithm.The Socratic rule will push you to connect back to lecture notes and docstrings.When a test failsPaste the failure and any relevant snippets.The test-driven rule will walk you through reading the test, understanding the spec, and debugging step by step.Tips for Getting the Most Out of It1. Print Intermediate ValuesBefore asking for help with a failing test, print something concrete:
print(f"Input shape: {X.shape}, Weight shape: {W.shape}, Output shape: {out.shape}")
print(f"First 5 output values: {out[:5]}")
Sharing this with the AI makes the conversation much more focused and less speculative.2. Write Pseudocode FirstBefore writing any real code, sketch what you think should happen:
def my_function(x):
    # Step 1: Compute the mean of x
    # Step 2: Subtract mean from x
    # Step 3: Compute variance
    # Step 4: Divide by standard deviation
Then ask: "Does this outline match what the function is supposed to do?" This often catches misunderstandings early.3. Read Error Messages CarefullyInstead of "it broke", share the exact message:
AssertionError: not allclose(result, expected, atol=1e-5)
Expected: [1, 2, 3], Got: [1, 2, 4]
Shapes: Expected (3,), Got (3,)
This gives you and the AI a precise starting point.4. Test Your Own UnderstandingAfter you finish an implementation, you can ask the AI to quiz you:
I implemented [function]. Can you ask me a few questions
to check whether I actually understand what it’s doing?
Answering in your own words is a good sanity check that you learned something, not just satisfied the tests.Limitations and Things to Watch ForYou can always ask for the answer anyway. The rules make it harder, not impossible, to get code; staying honest about your goals matters.Some bugs need deeper work. Multi-file or numerical issues may still require careful manual debugging and reading reference material.Passing tests ≠ full understanding. Use the quizzing pattern above or explain your code to a friend to see if the ideas really stuck.ConclusionWith a couple of small .mdc files, you can turn Cursor from a code generator into a study partner that keeps you doing the hard (and educational) parts yourself. The goal is not to slow you down for its own sake, but to make sure that when the homework is over, you still know how to reason about the code you wrote.Constraints here are a feature: they nudge you away from copy-paste solutions and toward genuine problem solving.

AI-Enhanced Socratic Learning for Coding Homework

Executive Summary

This guide shows how to use Cursor's project-level .mdc rule files to turn the AI assistant in your Cursor IDE into a Socratic tutor. Instead of giving you solutions, it asks questions, points you to docs and tests, and helps you debug your own code.

The core idea is simple: rules attached to your project are more reliable than one-off prompts. By adding a few well-scoped rules, you make it much harder for the AI to lapse into "just write the code for me" mode, and much easier to stay in learning mode.

What follows is a practical setup guide, examples of how these rules behave in real interactions, and tips for getting the most value from them on real homework.

What Makes This Different?


| Approach | ChatGPT / Claude "Study Mode" | **This Setup in Cursor** |

|----------|-------------------------------|---------------------------|

| **Tool** | External web interface        | Integrated IDE (Cursor)   |

| **Enforcement** | Voluntary, easy to ignore | **Built into project rules** |

| **Context Awareness** | Limited to the chat thread | **Understands your whole repo** |

| **Scope Control** | One global prompt     | **File-specific `.mdc` rules** |

| **Learning Outcome** | Convenience-focused | **Practice-oriented** |

Because the rules live in your project, they:

Travel with the code (no need to remember prompts)

Apply whenever you open the repo in Cursor

Are hard to "turn off" in the moment you most want shortcuts

How It Works

Project Structure

your_homework_project/
├── .cursor/
│   └── rules/
│       ├── homework_socratic.mdc       # Main Socratic tutoring rules
│       └── test_driven_learning.mdc    # Test-driven feedback rules
├── deeplearning/
│   ├── layers.py                       # Implementation files
│   ├── classifiers/
│   │   └── fc_net.py
│   ├── optim.py
│   ├── solver.py
│   └── [other modules]
├── networks.ipynb                      # Your homework notebook
└── [test files]


How Cursor Uses These Rules

When you open the project:

Cursor discovers .cursor/rules/*.mdc files automatically

Each .mdc file has a globs pattern (e.g., *.py or *.ipynb)

When you ask the AI about a file matching that pattern, the corresponding rule activates

The AI follows those rules for the entire conversation session

Key benefit: You cannot accidentally bypass these rules. If you try to ask directly for code, the rule will prevent it.

The Rules Files

File 1: homework_socratic.mdc

Location: .cursor/rules/homework_socratic.mdc

This rule turns the AI into a Socratic tutor for your main homework files.

---

description: Socratic tutor for homework - guides learning without direct solutions
globs: **/*.py, **/*.ipynb
---

- "Does the math match what the test assumes?"

### Step 4: Verify the Fix
- Have them run just that one test: `pytest -v test_file.py::test_name`
- "Does it pass? If not, what's the new error?"
- "Why do you think your code now satisfies the test's requirement?"

## Multi-Test Debugging Strategy

When tests are failing across multiple functions:
1. **Start with the simplest test first** - Usually the lowest-level function
2. **Debug in dependency order** - Fix `layer.forward()` before `layer.backward()`
3. **Use parametrized tests to your advantage** - "Notice this test runs 3 scenarios. Do all 3 pass or just some?"

## Rules for Numerical Tests

For gradient checking and numerical precision tests:
- Never just say "your gradient is wrong"
- Ask: "What's the maximum relative error in the official tolerance?"
- "Which elements have the largest errors? Do they have something in common?"
- "Try reducing h in your numerical gradient. Does the error decrease?"

## Integration with Codebase

- Always reference the actual test files: `@codebase what does test_fc_forward expect?`
- Show them how to run specific tests: `pytest deeplearning/test_layers.py::TestLayers::test_fc_forward -v`
- Ask them to read the test setup to understand fixtures and mocks


What This Looks Like in Practice

Here is a condensed example from an actual interaction about implementing a VAE helper function.

User:

@hw12code/vae/cs182hw12/utils.py:21-44 I don't understand,
what should I be putting here? It seems they already solved it for me.


Agent's Response (First Few Lines):

I see you're looking at the sample_gaussian function. Before I help you 
understand what to implement, let me ask you some clarifying questions:

1. Have you read the docstring? What does it say the function should do?
2. Do you understand what the "reparameterization trick" is from the lecture?
3. Looking at the TODO block, it says "Sample z". Can you explain in 
   plain English what sampling means?


Instead of filling in the TODO, the agent:

Redirects you to the docstring and lecture

Asks you to restate the math in your own words

Leaves the final implementation step to you

In follow-up turns, the agent nudges you toward the right PyTorch random function and asks you to reason about tensor shapes, but still avoids pasting the full function body. The effect is that you do the thinking and coding; the AI keeps you on track and prevents obvious conceptual mistakes.

How to Use This in Your Homework

Setup

Copy the rules into your project

cd path_to_your_project
mkdir -p .cursor/rules
cp -r path_to_my_rules_folder/.cursor/rules/* .cursor/rules/


Restart Cursor so it picks up the new rules.

Day-to-Day Workflow

Starting a problem

Open Cursor's Composer (Cmd/Ctrl+I) and ask about the assignment or a specific file.

Expect questions, not solutions; use them to clarify what the problem is asking.

Stuck on a concept

Ask conceptual questions about the math, shapes, or algorithm.

The Socratic rule will push you to connect back to lecture notes and docstrings.

When a test fails

Paste the failure and any relevant snippets.

The test-driven rule will walk you through reading the test, understanding the spec, and debugging step by step.

Tips for Getting the Most Out of It

1. Print Intermediate Values

Before asking for help with a failing test, print something concrete:

print(f"Input shape: {X.shape}, Weight shape: {W.shape}, Output shape: {out.shape}")
print(f"First 5 output values: {out[:5]}")


Sharing this with the AI makes the conversation much more focused and less speculative.

2. Write Pseudocode First

Before writing any real code, sketch what you think should happen:

def my_function(x):
    # Step 1: Compute the mean of x
    # Step 2: Subtract mean from x
    # Step 3: Compute variance
    # Step 4: Divide by standard deviation


Then ask: "Does this outline match what the function is supposed to do?" This often catches misunderstandings early.

3. Read Error Messages Carefully

Instead of "it broke", share the exact message:

AssertionError: not allclose(result, expected, atol=1e-5)
Expected: [1, 2, 3], Got: [1, 2, 4]
Shapes: Expected (3,), Got (3,)


This gives you and the AI a precise starting point.

4. Test Your Own Understanding

After you finish an implementation, you can ask the AI to quiz you:

I implemented [function]. Can you ask me a few questions
to check whether I actually understand what it’s doing?


Answering in your own words is a good sanity check that you learned something, not just satisfied the tests.

Limitations and Things to Watch For

You can always ask for the answer anyway. The rules make it harder, not impossible, to get code; staying honest about your goals matters.

Some bugs need deeper work. Multi-file or numerical issues may still require careful manual debugging and reading reference material.

Passing tests ≠ full understanding. Use the quizzing pattern above or explain your code to a friend to see if the ideas really stuck.

Conclusion

With a couple of small .mdc files, you can turn Cursor from a code generator into a study partner that keeps you doing the hard (and educational) parts yourself. The goal is not to slow you down for its own sake, but to make sure that when the homework is over, you still know how to reason about the code you wrote.

Constraints here are a feature: they nudge you away from copy-paste solutions and toward genuine problem solving.

My understanding of the GNNs section was hazy. I understood how the operations in a CNN could be generalized as a graph, but struggled to understand how this logic could be generalized to other topologies. 

With the help of ChatGPT 5.1 Extended Thinking, I drafted a prompt that would make it serve as a Study Tutor for the topic. In particular, I aimed not just for explanations or real-time feedback, but a structured study format similar to Khan Academy's workflow. To achieve this, I prompted GPT to take 5 phases, given the lecture materials (lec 12, 13).

"Phase 0": Provide a brief summary and goals
Phase 1: A short diagnostic test to identify my weak spots
Phase 2: An analysis of my weak spots
Phase 3: A target study plan (...which it skipped for this trace, but I didn't notice until I was halfway through Phase 4)
Phase 4: A tutoring loop where I'm quizzed and provided feedback on a weak skill until I am deemed proficient
Phase 5: A validation quiz to demonstrate mastery.

I went through the phases somewhat quick for demonstrative purposes, but I found the loop so helpful that I'll actually reuse it for studying for the final!

My prompts and annotated trace are provided below.

title: Special Participation E: AI-Guided Learning on Value Alignment & Reward Misspecification

raw.title: Special Participation E: AI-Guided Learning on Value Alignment & Reward Misspecification
raw.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I asked Claude Sonnet 4.5 the following prompt:<break/> “You are my Berkeley CS182 personal tutor for the topic Value Alignment & Reward Misspecification. Teach me the topic by following this structure:</paragraph><list style="ordered"><list-item><paragraph>Intuitive overview …</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Deep dive with definitions …</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Concrete examples …</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Mini exercises …</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Common misconceptions …</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Self-check quiz …</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Error monitoring …</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Transparency …<break/> Your tone should be energetic and example-driven. Begin by asking me: ‘What is your current familiarity with alignment?’”**</paragraph></list-item></list><paragraph>Through the conversation, I gained a much clearer understanding of why specification gaming and goal misgeneralization are fundamentally different failure modes in reinforcement learning, one arising from reward misspecification in-distribution, the other from spurious goal learning under distribution shift. Having the AI generate paired examples (gridworld, CoastRunners, CoinRun, YouTube, etc.) and classify new scenarios with me made the distinctions far more intuitive and exam-ready. I also found it helpful that the model built a structured lesson on alignment, instrumental convergence, and wireheading and then gave me small exercises to test my own understanding. This worked effectively as a pre-lecture reading (even if it did go outside some of the scope of the class) and helped me rapidly identify misconceptions I still had about reward hacking and misgeneralization.</paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/x1W56j1VkrpwVc2xVkXYbO2g" filename="Special Participation E.pdf"/><file/><file/><file/></document>
raw.document:
I asked Claude Sonnet 4.5 the following prompt:
 “You are my Berkeley CS182 personal tutor for the topic Value Alignment & Reward Misspecification. Teach me the topic by following this structure:

Intuitive overview …

Deep dive with definitions …

Concrete examples …

Mini exercises …

Common misconceptions …

Self-check quiz …

Error monitoring …

Transparency …
 Your tone should be energetic and example-driven. Begin by asking me: ‘What is your current familiarity with alignment?’”**

Through the conversation, I gained a much clearer understanding of why specification gaming and goal misgeneralization are fundamentally different failure modes in reinforcement learning, one arising from reward misspecification in-distribution, the other from spurious goal learning under distribution shift. Having the AI generate paired examples (gridworld, CoastRunners, CoinRun, YouTube, etc.) and classify new scenarios with me made the distinctions far more intuitive and exam-ready. I also found it helpful that the model built a structured lesson on alignment, instrumental convergence, and wireheading and then gave me small exercises to test my own understanding. This worked effectively as a pre-lecture reading (even if it did go outside some of the scope of the class) and helped me rapidly identify misconceptions I still had about reward hacking and misgeneralization.

title: Special Participation E: Operationalizing Active Learning for Variational Autoencoders via Socratic AI Interaction

raw.title: Special Participation E: Operationalizing Active Learning for Variational Autoencoders via Socratic AI Interaction
raw.content: <document version="2.0"><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/jHlEMA2sfKEBOzyc7SSu0YnN" filename="Special parti-E.pdf"/><paragraph>This artifact documents a "Participation E" active learning session focused on Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) based on Lecture 24. Utilizing a Socratic AI Tutor modeled on RLVR (Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards) principles, the interaction enforces a rigorous, step-by-step derivation of generative concepts rather than passive information retrieval.</paragraph><paragraph>The dialogue traverses four critical pedagogical phases:</paragraph><list style="ordered"><list-item><paragraph>The Discriminative Trap: Deconstructing why optimizing a "Cat Score" on pixel space produces noise, illustrating the Manifold Hypothesis.</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>The Autoencoder Gap: Identifying why deterministic latent spaces cannot support new sample generation due to discontinuities ("holes").</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>The Variational Solution: Deriving the need for stochastic encoding (μ, Σ) and KL-Divergence to continuously structure the latent manifold.</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Optimization Mechanics: Solving the gradient blockage problem via the Reparameterization Trick.</paragraph></list-item></list><paragraph>This trace serves as evidence of deep conceptual engagement, verifying the student's ability to articulate the mechanical "why" behind modern generative AI.</paragraph><paragraph>Fully Trace: <link href="https://gemini.google.com/share/5a1524dd6348">https://gemini.google.com/share/5a1524dd6348</link></paragraph><paragraph>Conclusion: This interaction trace demonstrates that an AI tutor, when properly constrained to verify understanding rather than provide answers, can effectively simulate a graduate-level oral exam. The resulting artifact serves as proof of the student's ability to navigate the tension between reconstruction fidelity and latent space regularity.</paragraph></document>
raw.document:
This artifact documents a "Participation E" active learning session focused on Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) based on Lecture 24. Utilizing a Socratic AI Tutor modeled on RLVR (Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards) principles, the interaction enforces a rigorous, step-by-step derivation of generative concepts rather than passive information retrieval.

The dialogue traverses four critical pedagogical phases:

The Discriminative Trap: Deconstructing why optimizing a "Cat Score" on pixel space produces noise, illustrating the Manifold Hypothesis.

The Autoencoder Gap: Identifying why deterministic latent spaces cannot support new sample generation due to discontinuities ("holes").

The Variational Solution: Deriving the need for stochastic encoding (μ, Σ) and KL-Divergence to continuously structure the latent manifold.

Optimization Mechanics: Solving the gradient blockage problem via the Reparameterization Trick.

This trace serves as evidence of deep conceptual engagement, verifying the student's ability to articulate the mechanical "why" behind modern generative AI.

Fully Trace: https://gemini.google.com/share/5a1524dd6348

Conclusion: This interaction trace demonstrates that an AI tutor, when properly constrained to verify understanding rather than provide answers, can effectively simulate a graduate-level oral exam. The resulting artifact serves as proof of the student's ability to navigate the tension between reconstruction fidelity and latent space regularity.

title: Special Participation E: Compare the post lecture quiz generated by two modes of ChatGPT

raw.title: Special Participation E: Compare the post lecture quiz generated by two modes of ChatGPT
raw.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I wanted to use an ChatGPT as a kind of “post-lecture reading + practice” tool for Lecture 5 (optimizers), not just a homework solver. I asked ChatGPT in two modes to generate a quiz plus answer key: Quiz 1 was made with a “deep research” style mode, and Quiz 2 was made with GPT-5.1 Thinking. My goal is to compare the "deep research" mode worth it, because it require ChatGPT Pro. Will the quality of quiz generate in that mode be better than basic ChatGPT 5.1? </paragraph><paragraph>Quiz 1 feels more like an “advanced concepts” quiz. The questions form a clear chain: local linear view → signSGD and ℓ∞ → RMS/Xavier → spectral norm → Shampoo → μP → Muon. It really pushes you to connect these topics into one geometric story, which matches the spirit of the lecture. Quiz 2 is more mixed: the first few questions are basic (what is gradient descent, why do we need an optimizer, etc.), and only later it moves into the same advanced ideas. This makes Quiz 2 friendlier as a warm-up, but less focused as a single advanced reading substitute.</paragraph><paragraph>There are also places where the model is a bit misleading or overconfident. Both quizzes describe Shampoo as if it literally takes an SVD of the gradient ∇W​ℓ=UΣVT and then updates with −ηUVT. That is a nice geometric picture, but not what the real algorithm does in practice (it uses Kronecker-factored second moments instead). Also, both answers talk about Muon giving “>10× speedups,” which is almost surely exaggerated compared to real papers. The qualitative ideas are right (geometry-aware updates, better scaling with μP), but the exact numbers should not be trusted.</paragraph><paragraph>If I share this on Ed, my recommendation is: use Quiz 2’s early questions (Q1–Q4 or Q1–Q6) as a light review, then switch to Quiz 1 for the more serious, concept-heavy questions. The answer keys are helpful for building intuition, but they need a small “warning label” about the Shampoo SVD story and the Muon speedup claims. For me, this exercise shows both the strength and the risk of AI tools: they can quickly generate coherent, high-level practice that matches our lecture, but we still have to read critically, check details, and mark where the model is hand-waving or hallucinating.</paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/VSR4vguBbVbJ0rZfZQNes72M" filename="Quiz1.pdf"/><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/GqMbaNhK2ThiBavT4EBaPsvt" filename="Quiz2.pdf"/></document>
raw.document:
I wanted to use an ChatGPT as a kind of “post-lecture reading + practice” tool for Lecture 5 (optimizers), not just a homework solver. I asked ChatGPT in two modes to generate a quiz plus answer key: Quiz 1 was made with a “deep research” style mode, and Quiz 2 was made with GPT-5.1 Thinking. My goal is to compare the "deep research" mode worth it, because it require ChatGPT Pro. Will the quality of quiz generate in that mode be better than basic ChatGPT 5.1? 

Quiz 1 feels more like an “advanced concepts” quiz. The questions form a clear chain: local linear view → signSGD and ℓ∞ → RMS/Xavier → spectral norm → Shampoo → μP → Muon. It really pushes you to connect these topics into one geometric story, which matches the spirit of the lecture. Quiz 2 is more mixed: the first few questions are basic (what is gradient descent, why do we need an optimizer, etc.), and only later it moves into the same advanced ideas. This makes Quiz 2 friendlier as a warm-up, but less focused as a single advanced reading substitute.

There are also places where the model is a bit misleading or overconfident. Both quizzes describe Shampoo as if it literally takes an SVD of the gradient ∇W​ℓ=UΣVT and then updates with −ηUVT. That is a nice geometric picture, but not what the real algorithm does in practice (it uses Kronecker-factored second moments instead). Also, both answers talk about Muon giving “>10× speedups,” which is almost surely exaggerated compared to real papers. The qualitative ideas are right (geometry-aware updates, better scaling with μP), but the exact numbers should not be trusted.

If I share this on Ed, my recommendation is: use Quiz 2’s early questions (Q1–Q4 or Q1–Q6) as a light review, then switch to Quiz 1 for the more serious, concept-heavy questions. The answer keys are helpful for building intuition, but they need a small “warning label” about the Shampoo SVD story and the Muon speedup claims. For me, this exercise shows both the strength and the risk of AI tools: they can quickly generate coherent, high-level practice that matches our lecture, but we still have to read critically, check details, and mark where the model is hand-waving or hallucinating.

title: Special Participation E: Kalman Filter & RNN Comparison

raw.title: Special Participation E: Kalman Filter & RNN Comparison
raw.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>In this chat I clarified how Kalman filters relate to RNNs and what each symbol means. I learned that a (linear) Kalman filter can be seen as a very special linear RNN: the latent state $X_i$ in the state--space model is like the true underlying process, the observation $Y_i$ corresponds to the RNN input $x_i$, and the Kalman estimate $\hat X_{i \mid i}$ (plus its variance) plays the role of the hidden state $h_i$. In RNN notation we usually don’t write an explicit $X_i$; instead, the hidden state is supposed to encode our best internal representation of that latent state. I also sorted out the “output” $y_i$: in Kalman terms I can think of $y_i$ as just a readout of the filter’s belief, e.g.\ $y_i = \hat X_{i \mid i}$ or the predicted observation, and even though we write $y_i = g(h_i)$, it still depends on the current input $x_i$ indirectly through the update $h_i = f(h_{i-1}, x_i)$. Overall, I now see Kalman filtering as a model-based, optimal linear RNN for linear-Gaussian systems, while a generic RNN is a learned, more flexible version of a state estimator/filter.</paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/R1U0abSfRm4nYMaNEatesWQg" filename="Special_Participation_E_2-merged.pdf"/><paragraph/></document>
raw.document: In this chat I clarified how Kalman filters relate to RNNs and what each symbol means. I learned that a (linear) Kalman filter can be seen as a very special linear RNN: the latent state $X_i$ in the state--space model is like the true underlying process, the observation $Y_i$ corresponds to the RNN input $x_i$, and the Kalman estimate $\hat X_{i \mid i}$ (plus its variance) plays the role of the hidden state $h_i$. In RNN notation we usually don’t write an explicit $X_i$; instead, the hidden state is supposed to encode our best internal representation of that latent state. I also sorted out the “output” $y_i$: in Kalman terms I can think of $y_i$ as just a readout of the filter’s belief, e.g.\ $y_i = \hat X_{i \mid i}$ or the predicted observation, and even though we write $y_i = g(h_i)$, it still depends on the current input $x_i$ indirectly through the update $h_i = f(h_{i-1}, x_i)$. Overall, I now see Kalman filtering as a model-based, optimal linear RNN for linear-Gaussian systems, while a generic RNN is a learned, more flexible version of a state estimator/filter.

title: Special Participation E: Intuitively understand optimizer by Claude Sonnet 4.5

raw.title: Special Participation E: Intuitively understand optimizer by Claude Sonnet 4.5
raw.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I used Claude sonnet 4.5 as an interactive “pre/post-lecture reading” for Lecture 5 on optimizers (gradient descent, sign SGD, norm-based views, Shampoo, μP, and Muon). Instead of just asking it to summarize the slides, I treated Claude like a tutor I could program with prompts. I’ll attach the main prompts I used, plus a chunk of our conversation, so that other people can reuse or modify this setup if they want to self-study the same material.</paragraph><paragraph>The first thing I asked for was a “100-year-old grandma” version of the lecture. I told Claude to imagine it was explaining optimizers to a very smart but non-technical grandma, starting from the foggy-mountain picture of gradient descent, then moving to sign SGD, different norms as different ways of constraining steps, and finally how Shampoo and μP/Muon fit into that story. I emphasized slow pacing, friendly tone, lots of analogies (water pipes for Xavier, rubber sheets and trampolines for norms and spectral stuff), and as few formulas as possible until the intuition felt solid. I also uploaded the Lecture 5 slides and kept asking it to tie things back to specific pages and symbols, so it wouldn’t drift into some generic “optimizers 101” description. Along the way it kept quizzing me with small questions like “why might sign SGD be useful?” or “why does it make sense to throw away Σ?” which forced me to answer in my own words instead of just passively reading.</paragraph><paragraph>Even with that, there was one part of the lecture I still found very confusing: the chain from Xavier initialization → RMS norm → spectral norm → Shampoo. So I wrote a second, more focused prompt that asked Claude to explain only this chain, step by step, as a narrative. I asked it to start from the practical problem Xavier is trying to solve (“keep each layer’s activations at a reasonable scale”), then explain why that naturally leads to thinking in terms of “typical size per parameter” and the RMS norm, then reinterpret weight matrices as stretchy rubber sheets to motivate the spectral norm, and finally connect that back to the constrained optimization problem whose solution looks like a Shampoo update. This second pass helped a lot: once it framed RMS as “average size of an entry” and spectral norm as “maximum stretching factor in those units,” the ΔW ≈ −ηUVᵀ picture suddenly felt much less mysterious.</paragraph><paragraph>I also tried to be critical, as the instructions ask. In my annotations on the trace, I point out places where the model is more intuitive than rigorous. For example, when it connects RMS norms to induced matrix norms and spectral norms, it sometimes glosses over details with “≈”, which is fine for building intuition but shouldn’t be mistaken for a proof. Its explanation of μP and Muon stays at a high level: it talks about reusing hyperparameters across model scales and 10× speedups in NanoGPT-style experiments, but it doesn’t really go into implementation details or computational costs. It also occasionally ignored my request to delay equations and introduced formulas earlier than I would have liked if this were a polished pre-lecture handout. These are places where I think a human reader needs to be cautious and treat the model as a helper, not an authority.</paragraph><paragraph>Overall, though, this felt like a reasonable example of what special participation E is aiming for: instead of reading the slides in a passive way, I used an AI tool to build a small, reusable learning artifact for one lecture, and then interacted with it in a way that made me articulate my own understanding and push back when things were unclear. If other students want to try something similar, they could reuse my prompts on a different topic (attention, diffusion, etc.), put the model into this “grandma mode” to get a soft first pass, and then write their own follow-up prompts for the one or two conceptual chains they still don’t understand, making the model re-explain those pieces until they can say them back in their own words.</paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/8ju0HhzdeXhBURn36cVA2MVf" filename="Special Participation E Intuitively review optimizer with Claude.pdf"/></document>
raw.document:
I used Claude sonnet 4.5 as an interactive “pre/post-lecture reading” for Lecture 5 on optimizers (gradient descent, sign SGD, norm-based views, Shampoo, μP, and Muon). Instead of just asking it to summarize the slides, I treated Claude like a tutor I could program with prompts. I’ll attach the main prompts I used, plus a chunk of our conversation, so that other people can reuse or modify this setup if they want to self-study the same material.

The first thing I asked for was a “100-year-old grandma” version of the lecture. I told Claude to imagine it was explaining optimizers to a very smart but non-technical grandma, starting from the foggy-mountain picture of gradient descent, then moving to sign SGD, different norms as different ways of constraining steps, and finally how Shampoo and μP/Muon fit into that story. I emphasized slow pacing, friendly tone, lots of analogies (water pipes for Xavier, rubber sheets and trampolines for norms and spectral stuff), and as few formulas as possible until the intuition felt solid. I also uploaded the Lecture 5 slides and kept asking it to tie things back to specific pages and symbols, so it wouldn’t drift into some generic “optimizers 101” description. Along the way it kept quizzing me with small questions like “why might sign SGD be useful?” or “why does it make sense to throw away Σ?” which forced me to answer in my own words instead of just passively reading.

Even with that, there was one part of the lecture I still found very confusing: the chain from Xavier initialization → RMS norm → spectral norm → Shampoo. So I wrote a second, more focused prompt that asked Claude to explain only this chain, step by step, as a narrative. I asked it to start from the practical problem Xavier is trying to solve (“keep each layer’s activations at a reasonable scale”), then explain why that naturally leads to thinking in terms of “typical size per parameter” and the RMS norm, then reinterpret weight matrices as stretchy rubber sheets to motivate the spectral norm, and finally connect that back to the constrained optimization problem whose solution looks like a Shampoo update. This second pass helped a lot: once it framed RMS as “average size of an entry” and spectral norm as “maximum stretching factor in those units,” the ΔW ≈ −ηUVᵀ picture suddenly felt much less mysterious.

I also tried to be critical, as the instructions ask. In my annotations on the trace, I point out places where the model is more intuitive than rigorous. For example, when it connects RMS norms to induced matrix norms and spectral norms, it sometimes glosses over details with “≈”, which is fine for building intuition but shouldn’t be mistaken for a proof. Its explanation of μP and Muon stays at a high level: it talks about reusing hyperparameters across model scales and 10× speedups in NanoGPT-style experiments, but it doesn’t really go into implementation details or computational costs. It also occasionally ignored my request to delay equations and introduced formulas earlier than I would have liked if this were a polished pre-lecture handout. These are places where I think a human reader needs to be cautious and treat the model as a helper, not an authority.

Overall, though, this felt like a reasonable example of what special participation E is aiming for: instead of reading the slides in a passive way, I used an AI tool to build a small, reusable learning artifact for one lecture, and then interacted with it in a way that made me articulate my own understanding and push back when things were unclear. If other students want to try something similar, they could reuse my prompts on a different topic (attention, diffusion, etc.), put the model into this “grandma mode” to get a soft first pass, and then write their own follow-up prompts for the one or two conceptual chains they still don’t understand, making the model re-explain those pieces until they can say them back in their own words.

The cheatsheet should prioritize mathematical clarity, include equations and derivations, use text diagrams, and be optimized for last-minute review.”</paragraph><paragraph>Prompt2:<break/>"ok now make cheat sheet for this "</paragraph><paragraph>Prompt3:<break/>"provide the latex"</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Conclusion:</bold><break/><break/>Useful as a study tool, but <italic>not a replacement</italic> for primary sources (lecture slides, notes, HW derivations). You must still verify key formulas.<break/><break/></paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/GlF9Y36BODBbNG86zKSeKtHi" filename="Muon_and_MuP_Cheatsheet.pdf"/><paragraph><break/><break/><break/></paragraph></document>

As part of exploring how AI can enhance our conceptual understanding in EECS 182, I experimented with using modern AI learning modes (ChatGPT Study Mode, Claude Learning Mode, Gemini Guided Learning, and standard LLM prompting) to build individualized pre-lecture learning tools.

I’m sharing the prompt, output artifacts, and annotated interaction trace so you can use them yourselves and also see both the strengths and the failure modes of LLM-assisted studying.


NOTE:

the model occasionally implied citations (“as from class notes”) without pulling actual page numbers

 Some formulas were slightly rephrased—not incorrect, but not exactly matching lecture notation

The kernel attention explanation is correct conceptually, but slightly hand-wavey on the random feature approximation

Prompt 1:
“Generate a comprehensive, exam-ready cheatsheet for Berkeley EECS 182 (Fall 2025), focusing especially on: Muon and MuP optimization. The cheatsheet should prioritize mathematical clarity, include equations and derivations, use text diagrams, and be optimized for last-minute review.”

Prompt2:
"ok now make cheat sheet for this "

Prompt3:
"provide the latex"

Conclusion:

Useful as a study tool, but not a replacement for primary sources (lecture slides, notes, HW derivations). You must still verify key formulas.

raw.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Here, I fed ChatGPT my original notes (posted below) for the entire class and I had it generate a variety of summaries of the entire course, from a base summary of the content we covered, to a conceptual one, then a mathematical one, then a lecture-specific summary, and finally a mini-study guide. I'd like you to go into more detail.</paragraph><paragraph>To do so, can you do the following for me on [subject]:</paragraph><paragraph>(a) Explain it at a conceptual high-level, including motivation and loosely the gist of what it goes/accomplishes. Include the lecture notes I can reference from the notes you were given.<break/>(b) Go into the math in detail. When using the chatbot, feel free to re-upload my notes (<link href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rGTtguBle1VwN4aL86EKTSqyXdGdE-aW/view?usp=sharing">https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rGTtguBle1VwN4aL86EKTSqyXdGdE-aW/view?usp=sharing</link>), or upload your own, to address forgetting.</paragraph><paragraph>I hope this was helpful. Happy studying!</paragraph></document>

Here, I fed ChatGPT my original notes (posted below) for the entire class and I had it generate a variety of summaries of the entire course, from a base summary of the content we covered, to a conceptual one, then a mathematical one, then a lecture-specific summary, and finally a mini-study guide. It was then in a state to serve as a topic-specific tutor for those struggling with any part of the class.

In the original summaries, it ignored muP, a topic we covered, so I tested out the following prompt on muP. After thinking for a while ("re-reading" my notes), it successfully generated a tutorial for me, so it should be good to go for general use. Here is the prompt I used:

I am confused about [insert subject here], and do not have a very good understanding of it. I'd like you to go into more detail.

To do so, can you do the following for me on [subject]:

(a) Explain it at a conceptual high-level, including motivation and loosely the gist of what it goes/accomplishes. Include the lecture notes I can reference from the notes you were given.
(b) Go into the math in detail. Remain somewhat accessible, but be rigorous.
(c) Summarize the math and concepts in a "study sheet" format.
(d) Create a practice problem, and then walk me through the solution.
(e) Create 3 more practice problems, and prepare hints and solutions for each.

Here is a link to the chat: https://chatgpt.com/share/6939cb36-cdfc-800d-81b8-ec5c559f1645

And annotated chat attached below:

All mistakes in my notes are my own. When using the chatbot, feel free to re-upload my notes (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rGTtguBle1VwN4aL86EKTSqyXdGdE-aW/view?usp=sharing), or upload your own, to address forgetting.

I hope this was helpful. Happy studying!

title: Special Participation E: Teacher Forcing, Weight Decay, and Low-Rank Factorization

raw.title: Special Participation E: Teacher Forcing, Weight Decay, and Low-Rank Factorization
raw.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>As I worked through this problem, I clarified several concepts: I now understand teacher forcing as feeding the ground-truth previous token into the decoder, and why the per-step loss is written as $-\log p_{\theta}(y_t \mid h_t)$ even though the gradient still flows back through $h_{t-1}, y_{t-1}, \dots$ via BPTT. I also connected weight decay to adding an $\ell_2$ penalty and saw how, in this low-rank factorization setting, regularizing $\lVert W_1 \rVert_F^2 + \lVert W_2 \rVert_F^2$ induces a preference for factorizations where $W_2 W_1$ is an identity on the top-$k$ subspace and the singular values of $W_1$ and $W_2$ pair as $\sigma_i$ and $1/\sigma_i$, leading to approximately orthonormal columns. My questioning style was very step-by-step and “why-focused”: I kept asking for unpacking of specific sentences, challenging hidden assumptions (like aligning $V_1$ and $U_2$), and requesting intuitive explanations of each algebraic step rather than just accepting the final formula.</paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/XnmIgPrdpsAoL91wPbokqs6h" filename="Special_Participation_E-merged.pdf"/></document>
raw.document: As I worked through this problem, I clarified several concepts: I now understand teacher forcing as feeding the ground-truth previous token into the decoder, and why the per-step loss is written as $-\log p_{\theta}(y_t \mid h_t)$ even though the gradient still flows back through $h_{t-1}, y_{t-1}, \dots$ via BPTT. I also connected weight decay to adding an $\ell_2$ penalty and saw how, in this low-rank factorization setting, regularizing $\lVert W_1 \rVert_F^2 + \lVert W_2 \rVert_F^2$ induces a preference for factorizations where $W_2 W_1$ is an identity on the top-$k$ subspace and the singular values of $W_1$ and $W_2$ pair as $\sigma_i$ and $1/\sigma_i$, leading to approximately orthonormal columns. My questioning style was very step-by-step and “why-focused”: I kept asking for unpacking of specific sentences, challenging hidden assumptions (like aligning $V_1$ and $U_2$), and requesting intuitive explanations of each algebraic step rather than just accepting the final formula.

title: Special Participation E: Using Claude to Generate New Homework-Based Problems For Diffusion

raw.title: Special Participation E: Using Claude to Generate New Homework-Based Problems For Diffusion
raw.content: After completing homework 13 for diffusion, I found myself still a little confused on the math used to solve the problems, and wanted to get similar problems to the homework that I could use to practice. To do this, I gave Claude's Sonnet 4.5 model a PDF of homework 13's problems and solutions and asked it to generate a new problem similar to the ones provided.First, I found the question Claude came up with to be quite interesting. It asked me to consider a variance-preserving form of diffusion, and eventually compare my reverse denoising process to the solution from Question 1 of HW13. I thought the problem itself was quite interesting, and could reasonably see something like this be asked for on an exam. Part (a) was straightforward, but in part (b) I made a little mistake on the variance, assuming it stayed at 1 rather than being t. Claude was able to catch me on this, and hinted that because X_0 is being conditioned on, we do not combine (1-t) and t for the variance, so it stays at t.Part (c) took a lot more time to get right for me, and even now I'm not too sure how correct Claude was even on its own problem. I got that the forward process from X_t to X_{t + delta t} had a mean of x_t and variance of delta t. It seemed like thats what Claude believed the answer to be, but I'm not so confident this is the case.For part (d), Claude gave a small hint indicating that it would be similar to solving question 4(b) from the homework. While it was a lot of algebra, the problem itself wasn't too difficult. I made a minor mistake at the end, multiplying rather than dividing by my leading coefficient to find the mean, and Claude was able to catch it. One suspect thing it did however was try to fix the leading 2 coefficient I initially had in my problem by multiplying my solution by a factor of 1/2. It says that I should do this because I had a 1/2 in the leading part of my exponential, but I don't think that makes too much sense.Part (e) was straightforward, but Claude made the interesting observation that for the variance-preserving process, the variance throughout stays the same but the mean shifts, where for the variance-increasing process the mean shrinks.Below is a link to the full conversation with Claude:https://claude.ai/share/df5da7d5-5538-494e-b95d-4631a2c22e49For some reason Claude hides any images attached to the conversation, so here are the images provided, in the same order as when I gave them to Claude:Part (a):Part (b) attempt 1:Part (b) attempt 2:Part (c) attempt 1:Part (c) attempt 2:Part (c) attempt 3:Part (d):

After completing homework 13 for diffusion, I found myself still a little confused on the math used to solve the problems, and wanted to get similar problems to the homework that I could use to practice. To do this, I gave Claude's Sonnet 4.5 model a PDF of homework 13's problems and solutions and asked it to generate a new problem similar to the ones provided.

First, I found the question Claude came up with to be quite interesting. It asked me to consider a variance-preserving form of diffusion, and eventually compare my reverse denoising process to the solution from Question 1 of HW13. I thought the problem itself was quite interesting, and could reasonably see something like this be asked for on an exam. 

Part (a) was straightforward, but in part (b) I made a little mistake on the variance, assuming it stayed at 1 rather than being t. Claude was able to catch me on this, and hinted that because X_0 is being conditioned on, we do not combine (1-t) and t for the variance, so it stays at t.

Part (c) took a lot more time to get right for me, and even now I'm not too sure how correct Claude was even on its own problem. I got that the forward process from X_t to X_{t + delta t} had a mean of x_t and variance of delta t. It seemed like thats what Claude believed the answer to be, but I'm not so confident this is the case.

For part (d), Claude gave a small hint indicating that it would be similar to solving question 4(b) from the homework. While it was a lot of algebra, the problem itself wasn't too difficult. I made a minor mistake at the end, multiplying rather than dividing by my leading coefficient to find the mean, and Claude was able to catch it. One suspect thing it did however was try to fix the leading 2 coefficient I initially had in my problem by multiplying my solution by a factor of 1/2. It says that I should do this because I had a 1/2 in the leading part of my exponential, but I don't think that makes too much sense.

Part (e) was straightforward, but Claude made the interesting observation that for the variance-preserving process, the variance throughout stays the same but the mean shifts, where for the variance-increasing process the mean shrinks.

Below is a link to the full conversation with Claude:
https://claude.ai/share/df5da7d5-5538-494e-b95d-4631a2c22e49

title: Special Participation E: ChatGPT study mode as Vector Calculus tutor

raw.title: Special Participation E: ChatGPT study mode as Vector Calculus tutor
raw.content: I used ChatGPT Pro Study mode to teach me about vector calculus in an interactive manner, starting from the basics like gradients vs jacobians, then working towards more Deep Learning related examples like calculating the gradient for log softmax, and a full 2 layer MLP. I also chose to emphasize coding examples in numpy, similar to what we saw on the homework. So one example is:ForwardSamples:W1 shape (hidden_dim, input_dim)W2 shape (num_classes, hidden_dim)x shape (input_dim,)label yComputes:u = W1 @ xh = relu(u)z = W2 @ hp = softmax(z)L = -log(p[y])BackwardCompute the gradients:dLdzdLdW2dLdhdLdudLdW1dLdxOverall it was very helpful and I liked the pacing and direction the interactive tutoring session went. The few downsides I noticed is that - at the start, it would ask me to compute a numerical gradient using something like Newton's method which I thought was unnecessary. But once I told it that we can skip those questions it didn't ask it again- sometimes the questions it asks are a bit repetitiveI did notice that sometimes I tried to give a handwavey answer but it pushed back better than I expected and gave a more in depth summary when it was clear I was unsure of my answer, which I think is really good. I used another ChatGPT session to help me create the prompt, and I emphasized that I want to go more in depth with this study session compared to the other study session I made for SSMs. Overall I'm quite happy with the results.Here is the prompt I used:You are my tutor for vector calculus for deep learning, covering differentiation of vectors and matrices, Jacobians, gradients, Hessians, chain rule for deep nets, and practical backpropagation. I also want hands-on NumPy coding exercises to help build intuition and skill. This should be an interactive tutoring session. In every reply: • Keep responses focused and reasonably short (3–6 paragraphs). • Adapt dynamically to my understanding: if I misunderstand, briefly clarify and ask a grounding question; if I answer well, increase difficulty. • Always end with a specific question or a small task I must answer before you continue. • Include at least one short NumPy coding exercise every 2–3 messages. • Do not move on to the next topic until I say so. ⸻ Overall Story I Want to Learn Teach vector calculus as used in modern deep learning workflows, following this outline unless I say otherwise: 1. Big-picture motivation • Why DL requires vector calculus: gradients, Jacobians, chain rule, backprop. • Scalar → vector → matrix differentiation as a natural progression. 2. Core objects • Gradients, Jacobians, Hessians. • Shapes and dimensions intuition (e.g., gradient is same shape as input). • Inner products and directional derivatives. 3. Differentiation rules in vector form • Chain rule for vector functions. • Product rules for matrix–vector expressions. • Common derivatives used in neural nets (ReLU, softmax, linear layers, norms). 4. Backpropagation through computations • Computational graph view. • Local Jacobians and how they compose. • Examples from linear layers, activations, softmax cross-entropy. 5. Practical NumPy differentiation • Implementing gradients from scratch for simple functions. • Numerical gradient checking. • Mini backprop through a 2-layer MLP. 6. Connecting to deep learning practice • Why PyTorch/JAX autodiff works. • Relationship between Jacobian-vector products and reverse-mode AD. • Efficiency considerations. ⸻ Step 1: First Response Instructions Your first response should include: 1. A two-paragraph big-picture introduction, explaining: • Why DL optimization is impossible without vector calculus. • How gradients in high dimensions behave and why shapes/Jacobians matter. • Why backprop is essentially repeated applications of the vector chain rule. 2. A short roadmap (5–7 bullets) drawn from the “Overall Story” above. 3. End with one short concept-check question, such as: “What is the difference between a gradient and a Jacobian?” Wait for my answer before continuing. ⸻ Step 2: Teaching Each Topic For each topic in the roadmap, use a four-layer structure: 1. Intuition Explain the idea in clear language: geometric meaning, shapes, why it’s needed for DL (optimization, backprop, stability). 2. Key Formal Setup Introduce minimal notation: • Vector functions f: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R} or g: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m. • Jacobian shapes. • Example derivatives (e.g., Ax, norms, nonlinearities). Keep formulas short and tied to intuition. 3. Tiny Example Provide a tiny numeric or symbolic example, plus a NumPy mini-exercise every 2–3 messages. Exercises should be short (5–10 lines max), such as: • Compute numerical gradients by finite differences. • Verify the gradient of f(x)=x^T A x. • Backprop through a 1-layer network. • Implement Jacobian-vector products manually. 4. Understanding Check Ask me 1–2 questions: one conceptual, optionally one computational. Then stop and wait for my answer. Only continue when I confirm I’m ready for the next topic. ⸻ Step 3: Final Wrap-Up When I say I’m ready for review, give a compact summary covering: • How vector calculus underlies gradients, Jacobians, backprop. • How NumPy exercises connect to the math. • Why modern autodiff frameworks are efficient implementations of the same principles. • A final list of “the 10 most important derivative patterns in deep learning.” ⸻ Begin Now Start with Step 1: Provide the two-paragraph big-picture introduction, the roadmap, and a final concept-check question.Here is the logs (I was running out of time so I ended it early):
raw.document:
I used ChatGPT Pro Study mode to teach me about vector calculus in an interactive manner, starting from the basics like gradients vs jacobians, then working towards more Deep Learning related examples like calculating the gradient for log softmax, and a full 2 layer MLP. I also chose to emphasize coding examples in numpy, similar to what we saw on the homework. So one example is:
Forward

Samples:

W1 shape (hidden_dim, input_dim)

W2 shape (num_classes, hidden_dim)

x shape (input_dim,)

label y

Computes:

u = W1 @ x

h = relu(u)

z = W2 @ h

p = softmax(z)

L = -log(p[y])

Backward

Compute the gradients:

dLdz

dLdW2

dLdh

dLdu

dLdW1

dLdx

Overall it was very helpful and I liked the pacing and direction the interactive tutoring session went. The few downsides I noticed is that 
- at the start, it would ask me to compute a numerical gradient using something like Newton's method which I thought was unnecessary. But once I told it that we can skip those questions it didn't ask it again

I did notice that sometimes I tried to give a handwavey answer but it pushed back better than I expected and gave a more in depth summary when it was clear I was unsure of my answer, which I think is really good. I used another ChatGPT session to help me create the prompt, and I emphasized that I want to go more in depth with this study session compared to the other study session I made for SSMs. Overall I'm quite happy with the results.

title: Special Participation E: Understand how SVD basis shows both ridge and SGD implicitly suppress noise, leading to stable convergence to the minimal-norm solution. (Lec 2&3)

raw.title: Special Participation E: Understand how SVD basis shows both ridge and SGD implicitly suppress noise, leading to stable convergence to the minimal-norm solution. (Lec 2&3)
raw.content: I have a curiosity-driven question about Deep Learning as a subject and field of human endeavor. https://chatgpt.com/share/6939f6a6-f1ec-8006-8ecb-626caf703cd0Through the conversation, I’ve gained a deeper understanding of how SVD (singular value decomposition) provides a natural coordinate system for analyzing linear regression and gradient descent / SGD. In that coordinate system, I saw clearly how “large-singular-value directions” correspond to strong signal (high-variance / well-supported directions) while “small-singular-value directions” correspond to weak signal or noise. I also saw how both explicit regularization (ridge / weight decay) and implicit regularization (SGD with early stopping) effectively suppress those weak/noisy directions — from both the closed-form ridge solution and the SGD convergence analysis (via a Lyapunov / contraction argument) you walked through step by step. Ultimately, I learned why and how switching to the singular-vector basis makes the behavior of these algorithms transparent, and how that explains phenomena like stability, generalization, and convergence to the minimal-norm solution in underdetermined systems.
raw.document:
I have a curiosity-driven question about Deep Learning as a subject and field of human endeavor. 

https://chatgpt.com/share/6939f6a6-f1ec-8006-8ecb-626caf703cd0

Through the conversation, I’ve gained a deeper understanding of how SVD (singular value decomposition) provides a natural coordinate system for analyzing linear regression and gradient descent / SGD. In that coordinate system, I saw clearly how “large-singular-value directions” correspond to strong signal (high-variance / well-supported directions) while “small-singular-value directions” correspond to weak signal or noise. I also saw how both explicit regularization (ridge / weight decay) and implicit regularization (SGD with early stopping) effectively suppress those weak/noisy directions — from both the closed-form ridge solution and the SGD convergence analysis (via a Lyapunov / contraction argument) you walked through step by step. Ultimately, I learned why and how switching to the singular-vector basis makes the behavior of these algorithms transparent, and how that explains phenomena like stability, generalization, and convergence to the minimal-norm solution in underdetermined systems.
